name: Wenjing Lou
content: CNSR@VT -- Complex Networks and Security Research at Virginia Tech Skip Menu Skip to Main Navigation Skip to Main Content Skip to Footer Return to Skip Menu Main Navigation Home News Archive People Faculty Students Visitors Alumni/Alumnae Openings Research Thrusts Demo Resources Useful Links Opportunities Publication By Year By Area By Type Education Courses Mentoring Return to Skip Menu Main Content Wenjing Lou W. C. English Endowed Professor of Computer ScienceProfessor of Electrical and Computer Engineering (by Courtesy)IEEE Fellow, ACM Fellow Department of Computer Science Virginia Tech, Northern Virginia Center 7054 Haycock Road Falls Church, VA 22043 Office: 304 NVC Tel: 703-538-3774 eMail: wjlou at vt dot edu Link to my Google Scholar profile About Me Wenjing Lou is the W. C. English Professor of Computer Science at Virginia Tech and a Fellow of the IEEE, and ACM. She holds a Ph.D. in Electrical and Computer Engineering from the University of Florida. Her research interests cover many topics in the cybersecurity field, with her current research interest focusing on privacy protection techniques in networked information systems and cross-layer security enhancement in wireless networks. Prof. Lou is currently on the editorial boards of ACM/IEEE Transactions on Networking, IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, and Journal of Computer Security. She is the Steering Committee Chair of IEEE Conference on Communications and Network Security (IEEE CNS), which is a conference series in IEEE Communications Society (ComSoc) core conference portfolio and the only ComSoc conference focusing solely on cybersecurity. Prof. Lou served as a program director at the US National Science Foundation (NSF) from August 2014 to August 2017. At NSF, her responsibilities included the Networking Technology and Systems (NeTS) program, a core program of the Computer and Network Systems (CNS) division within the Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering (CISE), and the Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program, a cross-cutting security program led by CISE/CNS. Honors and Awards IEEE INFOCOM Achievement Award, 2025 Virginia Tech College of Engineering Dean's Award for Research Excellence, 2024 ACM Fellow for contributions to information and network security, 2023 Virginia Tech Alumni Award for Research Excellence, 2018 Technical Recognition Award for contribution to Information Security and Privacy in Cloud Computing and Wireless Networks, from IEEE Communications Society, Technical Committee on Communications & Information Security, 2016 Virginia Tech College of Engineering Dean's Award for Research Excellence, 2015 IEEE Fellow for contributions in Network and Information Security, 2015 VT College of Engineering Dean's Award for Faculty Fellow, in recognition of extraordinary performance in research, 2014 WPI Sigma Xi Outstanding Junior Faculty Researcher Award, 2009 NSF Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Award, 2008 WPI Joseph Samuel Satin Distinguished Fellow for the 2006-07 academic year in recognition of her outstanding accomplishments and promise for future contributions in both teaching and scholarship Paper Awards Best Paper Award for paper "ProFLingo: A Fingerprinting-based Intellectual Property Protection Scheme for Large Language Models", by Heng Jin, Chaoyu Zhang, Shanghao Shi, Wenjing Lou, Y. Thomas Hou, in IEEE CNS 2024, Sept 30-Oct 3, 2024, Taipei, Taiwan. Dr. Vanu Bose Best Paper Award from The National Spectrum Consortium for paper "Out-of-Band Interference Management to Protect Radio Astronomy," by Naru Jai, Yi Shi, Luiz DaSilva, Y. Thomas Hou and Wenjing Lou, in IEEE MILCOM 2024 Best Paper Award for paper "mCore: Achieving Sub-millisecond Scheduling for 5G MU-MIMO Systems", by Yongce Chen, Yubo Wu, Thomas Hou and Wenjing Lou, in IEEE INFOCOM 2021, May 10-13, 2021, Virtual Conference. IEEE INFOCOM Test-of-Time Paper Award, 2020. IEEE INFOCOM Test of Time Paper Award recognizes papers published between 10 to 12 years ago (a three-year window) in the INFOCOM proceedings that have been most cited and widely recognized to have a significant impact on the research community. Our paper "Achieving Secure, Scalable, and Fine-Grained Data Access Control in Cloud Computing," by S. Yu, C. Wang, K. Ren, and W. Lou in the Proc. of IEEE INFOCOM 2010, was selected to receive this award in 2020. The Fred W. Ellersick MILCOM Award for the Best Paper in the Unclassified Technical Program for paper "Optimal power control with Channel uncertainty in ad hoc networks," authored by S. Li, Y.T. Hou, W. Lou, B. Jalaian, S. Russel, and B. MacCall, in IEEE/AFCEA Military Communications Conference, (MILCOM), Nov 12-14, 2019, Norfolk, VA. Best Student Paper Award for paper "SHARK-IA: An interference alignment algorithm for multi-hop underwater acoustic networks with large propagation delays," co-authored by H. Zeng, Y.T. Hou, Y. Shi, W. Lou, S. Kompella, and S. F. Midkiff, in ACM International Conference on Underwater Networks and Systems (ACM WuWNet'14), Nov. 12â14, 2014, Rome, Italy. Best Student Paper Award for paper "A secure three-party computational protocol for triangle area," co-authored by L. Liu, X. Chen, and W. Lou, in the 19th Australasian Conference on Information Security and Privacy (ACISP 2014), Wollongong, Australia, July 7-9, 2014. Best Paper Award for paper "Privacy-preserving multi-keyword text search in the cloud supporting similarity-based ranking", co-authored by W. Sun, B. Wang, N. Cao, M. Li, W. Lou, Y.T. Hou, and H. Li, in the 8th ACM Symposium on Information, Computer and Communications Security (ASIACCS 2013), Hangzhou, China, May 7-10, 2013. This is a very competitive conference, with acceptance rate = 35/216 = 16% in year 2013. Best Paper Award for paper "On broadcast authentication in wireless sensor networks", co-authored by Kui Ren, Kai Zeng, Wenjing Lou, and Patrick J. Moran, in the International Conference on Wireless Algorithms, Systems, and Applications (WASA 2006), Xi'an, China, August 15-18, 2006. Best Paper Runner-up Award for paper "On throughput efficiency of geographic opportunistic routing in multihop wireless networks", co-authored by Kai Zeng, Wenjing Lou, Jie Yang, and D. Richard Brown III, in the Fourth International Conference on Heterogeneous Networking for Quality, Reliability, Security, and Robustness (QShine 2007), Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, August 14-17, 2007.
